title: Beyond Meat Stock Is Volatile. Wall Street Is Excited Anyway.
text:
Text size

Beyond Meat stock is volatile—as seen in its 3.9% drop on Wednesday. Learning to trade hot, new, disruptive technologies trade is challenging, to say the least. That hasn’t stopped Wall Street from feeding the frenzy over the stock.

Wednesday, Canadian doughnut chain Tim Horton’s announced plans to scale back some Beyond Meat (ticker: BYND) promotions. That could have caused the drop. Or perhaps the decline was catalyzed by charges alternative meat is too heavily processed, making nutrients less “bioavailable.” That’s what celebrity chef James Peisker said on Fox Business show Varney & Co. Wednesday morning.

Higher volatility is something investors need to be ready for when buying into big new trends. Alternative-meat—meat that mimics actual animal protein and is intended as a substitute for meat eaters and not only vegetarians—is so new even seemingly small changes can impact corporate valuation meaningfully. Still, Wall Street believes in the alternative-meat industry.

“The meat industry stands at over $1.4 trillion and is set to reach $2.7 trillion by 2040,” writes Jefferies equity strategist Simon Powell in a Tuesday research report. “Alternative meat is still in an embryonic stage—our best case is $470 billion of total meat market by 2040, worst case a mere $90 billion.”

Powell says a “meat tax” implemented by environmentalists or China’s pork crisis could be catalysts for rapid alternative-meat adoption. Don’t forget, African swine fever is threatening a huge portion of Chinese supply, and China is the world’s largest consumer of pork.

“There are emerging calls for a Meat Tax, given the impact on the climate and increasing focus on the possible negative health consequences of a meat-heavy diet,” adds Powell in his report. “The recent introduction of increased sugar taxes around the world is one example of how the meat industry could be subject to a similar tax.”

Those are bold ideas and huge numbers. Beyond Meat, after all, is expected to sell about $416 million worth of alt-protein in 2020. If Powell is correct and Beyond Meat captures just 5% of his addressable market, then Beyond sales could grow to $23 billion, growing sales 22% a year on average for a generation. Early in a new product’s life-cycle, when market share is low, the possibilities seem limitless.

It sounds great, but investors need to beware of playing that game. Any end market, including protein, is complex, making top-down analysis a risky starting point.

Within the market for protein, for instance, there are different cultures, different animals, and different cuts of meat coming from the different animals. David Lipman, chief science officer of privately held Beyond competitor Impossible Foods, tells Barron’s that form and flavor aren’t barriers to product expansion. Still, there could be a limit to what consumers adopt. Maybe there won’t be a Beyond Meat rib-eye, bone-in steak in the future. If that’s the case, analysts could be overcooking the total addressable market.

Barron’s has already advised caution when considering Beyond stock, recently writing we would avoid Beyond Meat shares. So is this just sour grapes on our part? No, but we have to admit we have been wrong thus far. The company’s execution has been strong, with new products popping up in new locations, but we can’t get over valuation. Beyond trades for more than 20 times estimated next year’s sales. Since our story appeared more than three months ago, Beyond Shares have climbed 50%. It has been a bumpy ride though—shares hit more than $234 before falling to $153.99.

Of course, it is important to consider big secular trends, like Powell’s report does, but it’s equally important to stay grounded and not depend on the most optimistic scenarios to justify stock purchases.

Jefferies is hosting an “Alternative Meats Day” in New York in early December. Maybe that will be a catalyst for the alternative-meat sector. hopes to attend,

Powell is an equity strategist at Jefferies, he doesn’t cover or recommend the stock. Analyst Kevin Grundy covers the stock for the brokerage, and rates shares Hold with a $190 price target.
